Award.AwardTitle: Determining how a K+ channel affects development and cell fate in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration: For many years, it has been known that ion channels control muscle contraction and nerve function. Dr. Bates' group recently showed that ion channels are also important for cells to determine what type of cells they should become. It is completely unknown how an ion channel communicates with other known developmental signaling pathways to participate in cell-fate decisions. The Bates lab uses genetics and light-controlled channels to figure out exactly how ion channels communicate with the proteins that have long been known to specify cell fate decisions. These experiments will determine how different ion flow controls animal development on a molecular level. Dr. Bates has mentored several high school students, over twenty undergraduate students, and graduate students in laboratory research. Funds from this NSF grant enable her to continue inquiry-based teaching and mentoring. In addition, she encourages under-represented groups in science by teaching summer programs for under-represented groups in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mutations that disrupt a potassium (K+) channel called Kir2.1 cause birth defects such as cleft palate, small jaw, dental defects, and fusion of toes and fingers in mice and in humans. This K+ channel determines how readily neurons fire and muscles contract, but it was unknown how it could contribute to developmental signaling. To determine how this K+ channel affects developmental signaling, we studied a similar channel in flies called Irk2. Inhibition of Irk2 alters the pattern of the veins and the structure of the fly wing. 

Ion channels such as Irk2 regulate electrical activity in muscle and in neurons. Using this funding, we discovered that there is electrical activity in the precursor of the fruit fly wing and that there are spontanious spikes in calcium levels in these undifferentiated cells. Inhibition of Irk2 changes the electrical activity and the calcium activity. Funding for our project was used to discover that Irk2 is important for regulating the release of a signal called Dpp to instruct other cells what they should become. 

Funding from NSF allowed us to mentor six high school students in our lab for one semester each.  These students included four Hispanic female students, one Native American female student, and one Arabic male student. All five of these students presented their work at the end of the semester in an oral and poster presentation.  In addition, funding from NSF allowed us to mentor three undergraduate students in our lab including one Hispanic female undergraduate student, one black female student, and one Indian American male student.  These students also presented their work at conferences and at the UC Denver medical school.
